events.event_name: S&P Global Canada Services PMI Release (January)
events.description: The S&P Global Canada Services PMI fell to 45.8 in January, indicating a third consecutive monthly decline in service sector output.

facts.fact_text: The S&P Global Canada Services PMI fell to 45.8 in January from 46.5.

evidences.evidence_text: The S&P Global Canada Services PMI fell to 45.8 in January from 46.5

facts.fact_text: New business volumes in the Canadian service sector contracted for a fourteenth straight month.

evidences.evidence_text: New business volumes contracted for a fourteenth straight month

facts.fact_text: Employment in the service sector declined for a fifth consecutive month.

evidences.evidence_text: employment declined for a fifth month, though only modestly

facts.fact_text: Input costs rose sharply due to higher supplier prices and tariffs.

evidences.evidence_text: Input costs rose sharply, driven by higher supplier prices and tariffs

claims.claim_text: Tariffs have made trade with the US unprofitable for some firms.
claims.author: some firms

evidences.evidence_text: some firms cited tariffs as making trade with the US unprofitable

claims.claim_text: Business confidence remains positive due to expectations of stronger activity and easing trade uncertainty.
claims.author: service sector firms

evidences.evidence_text: business confidence remained positive, supported by expectations of stronger activity and easing trade uncertainty

claims.claim_text: Competitive pressures and weak demand limited the ability of firms to raise prices.
claims.author: S&P Global

evidences.evidence_text: competitive pressures and weak demand limited firms’ ability to raise prices

evidence.evidence_text: some firms cited tariffs as making trade with the US unprofitable
Weak demand led to a sharp fall in backlogs
Input costs rose sharply, driven by higher supplier prices and tariffs
employment declined for a fifth month, though only modestly
